title.value: Fast-Converging Simulated Annealing for Ising Models Based on Integral Stochastic Computing
title.justification: The title is clearly stated at the beginning and is reflected in the abstract and introduction.
title.quote: Fast-Converging Simulated Annealing for Ising Models Based on Integral Stochastic Computing

extractions.description: The paper introduces a fast-converging simulated annealing method for Ising models using integral stochastic computing with p-bits, achieving significantly faster convergence speeds for combinatorial optimization problems like the traveling salesman problem, maximum cut, and graph isomorphism.

type.justification: The paper provides empirical comparisons and evaluations of the proposed method against conventional methods and a quantum annealer.
type.quote: The proposed stochastic computing-based SA method is compared with conventional SA and quantum annealing (QA) with a D-Wave Two quantum annealer on the traveling salesman, maximum cut (MAX-CUT), and graph isomor- phism (GI) problems.

name.justification: The focus of the research is on improving optimization techniques for combinatorial problems using simulated annealing.
name.quote: The proposed method can search for a solution to a combinatorial optimization problem...

name.justification: The paper centers on improving the simulated annealing method using p-bits and integral stochastic computing.
name.quote: Fast-Converging Simulated Annealing for Ising Models Based on Integral Stochastic Computing

name.justification: Integral stochastic computing is a key method in the approach proposed by the paper.
name.quote: The proposed method approximates the p-bit function based on an extension of stochastic computing called integral stochastic computing.

name.value: Simulated Annealing with Integral Stochastic Computing
name.justification: The model is a variation of simulated annealing proposed by the authors, combining stochastic computing with the use of p-bits.
name.quote: We introduce fast-converging SA based on p-bits designed using integral stochastic computing.

is_contributed.justification: The proposed method is introduced in the paper as a contribution from the authors.
is_contributed.quote: In this brief, we introduce fast-converging SA method based on p-bits (spins).

is_executed.justification: The model is executed and evaluated in the paper's experiments.
is_executed.quote: We evaluate SA based on the conventional p-bits and the proposed stochastic computing methods for three typical combinatorial optimization problems with Ising models.

is_compared.justification: The proposed method is compared with conventional simulated annealing and quantum annealing methods.
is_compared.quote: The proposed method achieves a convergence speed a few orders of magnitude faster while dealing with an order of magnitude larger number of spins than the other methods.

referenced_paper_title.justification: This paper builds upon the concept of p-bits, which is discussed in the referenced paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: In [2], SA was applied to solve the traveling salesman problem (TSP) by finding solutions at the global minimum energy of an Ising model. The solution was based on invertible logic and was implemented with probabilistic bits (p-bits) that can achieve probabilistic bidirectional computing between inputs and outputs [3].

name.justification: This dataset is used to evaluate the proposed method's performance on solving the MAX-CUT problem.
name.quote: A MAX-CUT problem (G11) [29] is solved using an SA method without p-bits [30] and using the p-bit-based methods (conv and prop2).

referenced_paper_title.value: Solving maximum cut problems by simulated annealing
referenced_paper_title.justification: The MAX-CUT problem dataset is referenced in the context of evaluating the proposed method.
referenced_paper_title.quote: A MAX-CUT problem (G11) [29] is solved using an SA method without p-bits [30] and using the p-bit-based methods (conv and prop2).

name.justification: The TSP dataset is used to evaluate the performance of the proposed method.
name.quote: In [2], SA was applied to solve the traveling salesman problem (TSP) by finding solutions at the global minimum energy of an Ising model.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper references the TSPLIB as the source for TSP problems used in their evaluations.
referenced_paper_title.quote: A QUBO model for a TSP with n cities is defined...
